title: How would I find the probability for this statistics problem below? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are you looking for an exact answer or an approximation? The mean of X is 0.6*50 = 30. The standard deviation of X is approximately sqrt(0.6*0.4*50) = 3.4641. The distribution of X is close to normal in the center, so approximate answers to your questions are (A) 1 - Normdist(30.5,30,3.4641,true) = 0.4426, and (B) Normdist(26.5,30,3.4641,true) = 0.4426. I’m using the Excel notation. Using N as the standard cumulative normal distribution function you would write the answers as (A) 1 - N[(30.5 - 30)/3.4641] and (B) N[(26.5 - 30)/3.4641]. For the exact answer, the number of ways you can get a sample with X = x is C(9000,x)*C(6000,50-x). The sum of these is C(15000,50). The probability of X = x is just the ratio, C(9000,x)*C(6000,50-x)/C(15000,50). That gives slightly different answers, (A) 0.1559 and (B) 0.4462. However the normal approximation is much less reliable in the tails. It gives a probability nearly 1,000 times too high for x = 50, nearly five times too high for x = 45 and 30% too large for x = 40. So be careful for using it on low probability events.
